title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Jar That Fixed My Winter Face
body:
Okay so. My skin in winter is a disaster. Like, a legit disaster. It’s not just dry. It’s tight, it’s flaky in patches, it gets red and angry if I look at it wrong, and every fancy lotion I’ve ever bought just sits on top and does nothing. Or makes it worse. I’ve spent so much money. The $80 cream from that fancy store at the mall? Made my cheeks feel like they were burning. The “intense repair” drugstore stuff in the blue tub? Just greasy. Greasy and still flaky. It was so frustrating. I was scrolling on my phone one night, battery at like 12%, just annoyed, and I kept seeing stuff about tallow balm for dry skin. Beef fat. For your face. I thought it was a joke at first. Seriously. But I was desperate. And my skin was so bad it felt like it might just crack off. So I figured, what’s the weirdest thing that could happen.

I ended up getting this Whipped Tallow Balm with lavender. From some small shop on Etsy. Made in France, from grass-fed cows, all that. It sounded… peaceful. Lavender, sleep, calming. My winter anxiety skin needed calming. I clicked buy. And then I forgot about it.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Even Became a Thing I Tried

When the jar showed up, it was smaller than I thought. Cute little glass jar. I opened it. It looked like… whipped butter. Honestly. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. Solid but soft? Kind of waxy but also creamy. I smelled it. Smelled like lavender maybe? Or not. Something. Herbal. Like the plant, not a candle. That was a good sign.

Here’s the thing I read after I bought it, which made me feel less crazy: beef tallow is supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it absorbs deep instead of just coating the top. It makes sense when you think about it. Old school thing. Good for winter damage, for psoriasis, for just… parched skin. My skin was definitely parched.

So that first night, I washed my face. It felt tight already, the way it does. I took a tiny scoop. Rub it between your fingers to warm it up—it melts fast. Then I just patted it on. Everywhere. Face, neck. My poor, sad knuckles.

It felt… different. Not greasy. Not slick. It was there, but it was sinking in. My skin drank it. Drank it like it was thirsty. Which it was. I went to bed feeling like I had a light film on, but not sticky. Just… protected.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does (Or Did, For Me)

I didn’t expect a miracle. I really didn’t. But I kept using it. Night cream, every night. Sometimes in the morning if I was staying in. After a few days, I noticed something. The tight feeling was gone. Like, gone gone. When I’d wake up, my face felt soft. Not “product” soft. My-skin soft. The flaky patches on my forehead and beside my nose? Started to smooth out. Not instantly. But they were healing.

The lavender part… that’s the genius bit for a night cream. It’s not a strong perfume smell. It’s just this quiet, herbal smell. Timeless, I guess. When I put it on, it’s like a signal to my brain. Okay. Day is done. Time to wind down. It’s soothing. For real. My nighttime routine became this little two-minute ritual of calm. Rub the balm, smell the lavender, done. Anxiety relief in a jar. Who knew.

I started using it on my elbows. And my heels. Winter destroys my heels. They get so rough. This stuff? Worked better than the heavy-duty foot cream I had. It just… absorbed. Deeply. No residue on my sheets. Big win.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been a few weeks now. Maybe a month? I lost track. Here’s where I’m at.

My skin isn’t “perfect.” I don’t think that’s a thing. But it’s calm. It’s hydrated. It doesn’t hurt. The redness has chilled out so much. When I put on my makeup now, it doesn’t cling to dry patches because… there aren’t any. It’s just even. That’s the best word. Even and comfortable.

I told my sister about it. She has psoriasis sometimes on her hands. She was skeptical too. “You put what on your face?” But she tried some of mine. Texted me two days later like, “Okay what is this magic, my knuckles aren’t cracking.” So. There’s that.

I’m on my second jar now. I got it from the same Etsy shop, **WildHarvestCreations**. I just went back and ordered it. No hesitation. It’s become my go-to natural moisturizer for dry, sensitive, winter-wrecked skin. It’s the best tallow for that deep, lasting moisture that doesn’t just sit there. It works.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did.

Look, if your skin is being difficult—if it’s dry, reactive, flaky, just generally pissed off—and nothing in a plastic bottle is helping, this might be worth a shot. It sounds weird. It is weird. But it’s a good weird. It’s one of those simple things that just… works. My face hasn’t felt this normal in years. Maybe ever.

It’s not a miracle cream. It’s a really good, simple moisturizer that your skin understands. Because it’s basically food for your skin. Weird to think about, but true.

Anyway. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

---

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it can be. Especially if you have dry or sensitive skin. The logic is it’s super similar to the oils our skin already makes, so it absorbs way down and helps repair the skin barrier. It’s an old-school remedy that’s making a comeback for a reason.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me, and I can get clogged pores easy. Because it’s so similar to our sebum, it seems to absorb cleanly. It doesn’t feel like it’s sitting on top and blocking things. But everyone’s skin is different, you know? Always patch test.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like actual lavender. Herbal, a little earthy, clean. Not like a sweet perfume or a candle. It’s a calming, sleep-promoting kind of smell. It’s subtle. Fades pretty quick after you put it on, but it’s nice while it’s there.

So yeah. If you’re curious about trying a tallow balm for dry skin, this lavender one is a solid place to start. It just works. I don’t know what else to say.
